section.section: On or after October 1, 2011, a surface owner of real property that is subject to a mineral interest may maintain an action to terminate a dormant mineral interest.

A mineral interest is dormant for the purpose of this subtitle if:
The mineral interest is unused for a period of 20 or more years preceding the commencement of termination of the mineral interest; and
Notice of the mineral interest was not recorded during the period of 20 or more years preceding the commencement of termination of the mineral interest.
The action must be in the nature of and require the same notice as is required in an action to quiet title as set forth in § 14-108 of the Real Property Article.
The action may be maintained, whether or not the owner of the severed mineral interest is an unknown or missing owner.
The injection of substances for the purpose of disposal or storage does not constitute use of a mineral interest.

A surface owner of real property that is subject to a mineral interest who brings an action to terminate a dormant mineral interest in accordance with this section shall bring the action in the circuit court of the jurisdiction in which the real property is located.

A court order that terminates a mineral interest merges the terminated mineral interest, including express and implied appurtenant surface rights and obligations, with the surface estate in shares proportionate to the ownership of the surface estate, subject to existing liens for taxes or assessments.
A court order that terminates a mineral interest shall identify:
The clerk of the court that issued the order shall record the order in the land records.

text.section:
This section shall apply notwithstanding any provision to the contrary in:
The instrument that creates, reserves, transfers, leases, divides, or otherwise evidences the claim to, or the continued existence of, the mineral interest; or
Another recorded document, unless the instrument or other recorded document provides an earlier termination date.
